item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: @schoppik There's always the null hypothesis. No effect on proteins. If there are effects, are they good or bad?I am not a molecular biologist. I can't tell you the deets. But others can and hopefully will.

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @ekmiller how do you envision that the electrical fields confine their effects to neurons? Wouldn‚Äôt they also affect the cytoskeleton in nearby vasculature? Or glia? Asking bc it‚Äôs hard to apply ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad‚Äù to trophic/metabolic players.

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description: Wait - what? Kurt Vonnegut too! I promise that I'll stop talking about the history of weather control research as soon as it gets boring. But that moment isn't here yet.Anyone who has read Kurt Vonnegut's Cat's Cradle will remember ice-nine (which turns water solid). So K. Vonnegut got that idea from his brother, Bernard Vonnegut who worked for GE and was one of the first to control weather (circa 1946) by throwing some dry ice out of a plane into the clouds to make it snow.https://www.ge.com/news/reports/cool-science-vonnegut-ge-research

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Why squirrels get dark in the city https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.02.02.526896v2

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
Any recommended reading about the somewhat bonkers history of weather control?Weather control has an absolutely fascinating history - it includes events like the US prolonging the monsoon season during the Vietnam war (by peppering clouds with silver nitrate) and China cloud seeding during the 2008 Olympics so it didn't rain on the wrong days. Weather control was a huge goal of science in the 1950 and 60s:
https://www.nsf.gov/nsb/publications/1965/nsb1265.pdf
but has fallen a bit out of favor since we've realized how complicated the weather really is.Someone must have written an amazing book about all of this history and the science behind it. Any leads? Maybe this one - anyone read it?http://cup.columbia.edu/book/fixing-the-sky/9780231144124

item.title: Glyn Moody
item.description: ‚ÄòThe whole thing stinks‚Äô: UK water firms to pay ¬£15bn to shareholders as customers foot sewage bill - https://theguardian.com/money/2023/may/20/the-whole-thing-stinks-uk-water-firms-to-pay-15bn-to-shareholders-as-customers-foot-sewage-bill it's simple: no dividends until the infrastructure is upgraded, and no price rises. if investors don't like it, they can move elsewhere.investors do not have an inviolable right to dividends; the public does have a right to rivers and seas without sewage - if companies can't do this, nationalise them

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: @schoppik We don't claim that they confine their effects to neurons. Electric fields can tune it all up. They play a role outside the nervous system. EFs are involved in embryonic development, cell migration, etc.

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: @schoppik EFs are ideal for tuning up any bio system. Tuning a system means getting the parts to harmonize. EFs spread and share influences at the speed of light.

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: @BorisBarbour @neuralreckoning @WorldImagining @polka @cshperspectives lol. Sounds like a corollary is that if there‚Äôs no preprint, then the authors weren‚Äôt interested in sharing, they just wanted a line in their CV.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: @sls @neuralreckoning @WorldImagining @polka @cshperspectives Of course, my statement doesn't necessarily imply yours. But what would be the reasons not to preprint?

item.title: tomstafford
item.description: Short-term incentives of research evaluations: Evidence from the UK Research Excellence Framework https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048733323000136More papers submitted just before the REF deadlines, compared to just after, and those papers submitted just before are less highly cited, less diverse and more likely to be retracted1/#metaresearch #metascience

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: @BorisBarbour @neuralreckoning @WorldImagining @polka @cshperspectives I‚Äôve been posting preprints for a long time. What throttles the flow of fake preprints? I‚Äôve seen items of questionable rigor that make it to preprints, so it‚Äôs not zero, but it does seem like there is less fake stuff in preprints. Is it ban policies at preprint servers that are more aggressive than for-profit publishers would like to adopt? Or is it that many places promote more for publications than preprints (so if more places modernize their promotion metrics, will we end up with more bad preprints)?

item.title: Dan Goodman
item.description: To UK academics (students and staff).‚ö† If you're offered work marking in the next months, please say no!It's likely an attempt to break our marking and assessment boycott, our most effective industrial action to avoid threatened pay cuts.Please boost if you have UK followers.#ucu #ucurising #academicchatter

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: Press release about our new theory: Cytoelectric coupling. Here's the idea in a nutshell:Neural oscillations carry information. The fluctuating electric fields are a way for the information the brain is processing to fine-tune the molecular structure of the brain so that it processes information more efficiently. Mind to molecules, if you will.https://picower.mit.edu/news/mind-molecules-does-brains-electrical-encoding-information-tune-sub-cellular-structure

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: Why do you need electric fields?Tuning networks means harmonizing them so that the components work together better. You can't do that one piece at a time. The components need to influence one another as they work. Electric fields spread influences at the speed of light.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: @sls @neuralreckoning @WorldImagining @polka @cshperspectives I share your impression about the overall quality of preprints. I think for now only genuine researchers who are proud of their results have any interest in preprints.
